repnme.cdata!:
Mauritius - Technical Assistance to Enhance
            Competitiveness Project

abstracts.cdata!:
The project rating is highly
            satisfactory, and so is its sustainability. All of its
            components offer valuable lessons. The Metrology, Standards,
            Testing, and Quality (MSTG) component reveal that
            accreditation of the domestic service provider, by reputable
            international organizations, and the establishment of
            twinning arrangements, are effective alternatives to
            traditional bureau arrangements standards. Public awareness
            is essential for quality, and standards, and, the
            integration of local organizations, should be set in
            accordance with international standards organizations,
            bearing in mind that export performance is heavily dependent
            on the initial demand for MSTQ services. Trade facilitation
            is desirable for a private corporation to own , and operate
            electronic infrastructure, and, should include comprehensive
            training of customs officials, in addition to customs
            departments reorganization, if needed. Electronic
            infrastructure should be flexible, so as to engage in other
            value-added network activities. As for the retirement system
            review, a comprehensive actuarial analysis is suggested to
            take place, prior to reforms, and, it is further reinforced
            that portable pension plans can eliminate constraints for
            labor mobility between private, and public sectors.
            Effective management of the Technology Diffusion Scheme
            should be accompanied by Government support, and a
            public-private oversight committee to build-on required schemes.

repnme.cdata!:
Mauritius - Technical Assistance to Enhance
            Competitiveness Project

abstracts.cdata!:
The overall objective of the Technical
            Assistance to Enhance Competitiveness Project is to help
            enhance export competitiveness and thereby prospects for
            sustainable rapid growth by facilitating private sector
            access to know-how for improved productivity, quality,
            design and response time, as well as diversification of
            export production. The project consists of: a) promoting the
            diffusion of good technology practices through a Technology
            Diffusion Scheme which will share the cost in improving the
            private sector's access to productivity, quality, and
            design services, and to information on new technologies; b)
            strengthening the MSTQ (metrology, standards, testing,
            quality) infrastructure to improve export quality; c) trade
            facilitation through the implementation of a program to
            speed up the process of trade documentation clearance, and
            to streamline critical procedural and operational areas in
            import and export documentation, with the aim of eliminating
            the need to physically present documents to the various
            organizations concerned. To ensure that these initiatives
            lead to tangible and early results, the project will also
            support the implementation of economic and regulatory
            reforms outlined in recent sector work, specifically
            provision of technical assistance: in restructuring the
            investment authorization process to improve the acquisition
            of foreign technology; in reviewing and restructuring the
            retirement savings system to improve flexibility in factor
            markets; and in developing competitiveness and productivity
            indicators to improve access to information by both the
            private and public sectors.
